description:
Heavy water consists of one oxygen atom and two deuterium atoms, a stable isotope of hydrogen also known as hydrogen-2. It has a density of 1.107 g/mL, making it about 10% heavier than ordinary water. Said to taste slightly sweet.

There is a common misconception that heavy water is radioactive, when in fact it is not. It is mostly safe to consume, as there are no health effects until about 25% of the water in the body has been replaced by heavy water. It is lethal in mammals when 50% of the water in their body has been replaced by heavy water, though it hasn't been tested on humans to this concentration.

Semiheavy water consists of one oxygen atom, one hydrogen atom, and one deuterium atom, a stable isotope of hydrogen also known as hydrogen-2. It has a density of 1.054 g/mL, making it about 5% heavier than ordinary water. About 0.03% of ordinary water is actually semiheavy water.

Heavy-oxygen water consists of two hydrogen atoms and one atom of either oxygen-17 or oxygen-18, both of which are stable isotopes of oxygen. It has a density of 1.11 g/mL, making it 11% heavier than ordinary water.

Tritiated water consists of one oxygen atom and two tritium atoms, and unstable isotope of hydrogen that is also known as hydrogen-3. It has a density of 1.21 g/mL, making it 21% heavier than ordinary water. Tritium has a halflife of 12.32 years and decays into helium-3 through beta decay. It is safe externally, as beta particles are unable to penetrate the skin, but is a radiation hazard when ingested.
